Beliefs aren't located anywhere in experience, they actually aren't experienced by definition. Beliefs are an assumption you make to make up for a lack of experience.

Beliefs are concepts which aren't experienced. Similar to the word "non-existence". It defines itself as something that isn't experienced.

As an example, you can't believe in Santa if Santa is standing in front of you. That becomes a fact not a belief. If you're experiencing it, it isn't a belief.

The belief that there is something separate from our current experience called "me" creates our self-image, and that self-image is a bundle of descriptions that attempt to describe this entity called "me", although the entity is never experienced outside of that self-image in the first place. Thus, it is only a belief.
if the word is making a distinction then its pointing at something

> In essence, we think our self-image is literally us? We think it's representing us?

In essence, you think it's possible to not be yourself. That's why there is an effort to figure things out about yourself. 

You think you're missing some knowledge about yourself which will solve who you are, which itself is the misunderstanding. Because you can't be what you aren't being right now, so whatever you gain in knowledge will be false.

> Does the self-image not even symbolize us? I thought it was just a symbol... Do symbols not really exist?

The function of a symbol is that it is never what it is pointing at.

The word cat is not a cat. Cats don't describe cats, words do.

The symbol exists as a physical/sensory phenomenon which causes you to imagine something. You read "pink elephant" and it causes you to imagine a pink elephant. Not because what you read is a pink elephant, but because you know what to imagine when you read these words. Words and symbols "instruct" you to imagine things, like pink elephants. This is how communication/understanding in language works. 

The self-image is a collection of descriptions and symbols about yourself, but the actual occurrence of "you" can never describe itself, for the same reason a cat doesn't describe a cat. The symbol is not what it is pointing at.

It's like drawing a picture and asking "is the picture ***really ***symbolizing me?" The picture is never what it is about. Our ability to think is like constantly drawing these pictures over and over again trying to recognize what we are in one of them, but the function of the thought is to never be what you are trying to think of. It's a symbol.

hypothetically...

Lets say since birth, you were taught about unicorns. Everyone taught you about them. Your parents. School. etc.

Then one day you came up to me and said im trying to find this unicorn and i tell you that there is nothing to find

Then you say what do you mean there is nothing to find? I still dont see any unicorns

And then i say Yes exactly, you dont see them, theres nothing there to find. There arent unicorns. They dont exist

And then you say but how do you know?

And then i say You cant know it, because it isnt there. Thats the whole point. There is nothing to know. You cant know nothing because then that would be something.

And then you say but thats not satisfying, thats just like a non-answer, bro and then you go back to looking for unicorns, and the ironic thing is that youre only looking for unicorns precisely because there is no unicorn in your experience. And so it causes you to endlessly to search for what is never in your experience, AKA unicorns. Its a koan. 

Now what would convince such a person that there are no unicorns? Is it more knowledge? Some future experience to cling onto? Some insight in the future? No, the future is only a mental carrot. Only observing what is currently experienced will do for such a person.

The reason the mind is so convincing is because it comes up with these self-fulfilling "searches". If it isn't in my experience, that means I haven't waited long enough. If I wait longer, what isn't appearing now will appear. This type of stuff.

The feeling is not actually caused by the prediction, it's caused by the belief or assumption that the prediction will happen to "you". 

In a similar way, learning what "death" means does not cause fear. It is when you have the thought "I will experience death" that fear comes, but the "I" is separate from that knowledge and never seen or experienced.

When you say "I will experience bad weather", the assumption is that there is something separate from the weather prediction which will experience bad weather. And that assumption feels like anxiety or worry in real time.

If you inspect direct experience, all feelings and emotions happen ***now***. Which means it is not possible that the emotion is caused by the future, because you never experience the future. It's kind of like if you touched a hot stove and said "oh shit this burns because the stove manufacturer created this 20 years ago, and I can't travel back 20 years in the past, guess I'm doomed". There is no actual time component to the emotion, that is a conceptual illusion. The emotion is simply how the currently appearing thought feels, in the same way how the burning sensation is how the stove currently feels. You can't feel the stove in the past and you can't feel the stove in the future. The emotions and feelings are ***not*** caused by what the thought is describing, because the thought is describing the future, and you can't feel the future because it does not experientially exist. Anxiety is the belief that you can experience the future, and that belief is felt currently.

This ties back to how you can feel fear by assuming a bear is in the closet without seeing the bear. Similarly, you feel anxiety by assuming the future exists, even though it is never seen or experienced. The reason I say that the thought never lands is because the one who is worried about the future must believe they are going to experience the future, but you never do.

It's not wrong to think, it's just that you have to think now, not in the past or future. If you're thinking about the change you experienced over time, you are exactly not experiencing that right now, which is why you have to think of it in the first place.

The search for self-knowledge is an assumption that you exist in the past or that you have to travel into the future in order to understand yourself better, but you can't actually use time travel to understand yourself, it's perfectly self-regulated so that you don't have to physically go to the past or future in order to understand yourself.

For example, you don't have to travel into the past in order to know what you did yesterday, and you don't have to travel into the future because you don't experience the future by definition. What you have always experienced is always just what you know right now, and that is all you will know.

Yes.

All of "physicality" only happens now. 

You can look at a rock now, store a memory of it. The memory of the rock precisely means "it isn't happening now." That's what a memory is. If the rock is still in experience, it isn't a memory.

"What do I want to do?" is a useless question by itself in the sense that its only function is to create an answer. And the answer you come up with in response to it is all that really matters, because there is no "me" you can find and question which will tell you what you want to do. I'm always doing what I want to do, in the sense that I'm always experiencing what is happening now, and that question is like a new invention in the now. So then in accordance with that, what I'm doing becomes me asking myself "what do I want to do?" It's not a resolution of some conflict, it's just a question being asked presently. Without the question, there is no answer.

There's no "me" i can refer to and ask "so what is it that you wanted to do?", so it makes more sense to just skip to "i want to do this..." instead of philosophizing about the non-existent person that is wanting to do things. You experience what you want by thinking of it. There is no other thinker to consult and ask "what did you want to do?"

The heart of self-inquiry is stepping back from the beliefs and notions and questioning "Who are the beliefs actually affecting? Why do I think it affects me? Where is the separate me in the picture that is affected by all this?"

"opening the closet" is realizing there isn't a separate you that is affected by beliefs

It isn't necessary to fact check, it's about going meta and zooming out and saying "Who is actually experiencing the thought or belief? How does it relate back to me?"

When you say "my beliefs", whose beliefs? If you can't find the believer, then no one is experiencing the belief, and thus there is no one troubled by the belief either. What you are checking is ultimately "who is experiencing the belief or thought? who is experiencing true or untrue beliefs?"

You cant confirm what will happen 10 years in the future, but who is actually affected by that extrapolation? There is no one affected by the future without thinking of the future, they are both the same singular occurrence and there is no separation.

There doesn't need to be contradiction or confusion in order to ask a question. The questions bring up the contradictions. When you talk to "SR people", we ask you questions.

There's no inherent question, there's an assumption of a separate self which can be questioned and seen to not actually be experienced. Bringing forth the questions is what self-inquiry is about. Believing in Santa isn't a question, but it creates emotions around the belief, even though Santa isn't experienced. You can confidently believe in Santa. But you can also ask questions about Santa while believing in Santa. That entire experience can be questioned, even if Santa is confidently believed in. You can always ask questions and scrutinize whatever you believe you are experiencing, because you are always experiencing what you are experiencing. If you question Santa long enough, it can eventually be resolved that "I've never directly experienced Santa and never will" and then you realize there is no point in believing in Santa anymore. The questions guide you towards checking your experience of yourself, and when you see the thing you're imagining isn't actually in your experience, you stop worrying about it. If you assume there is a bear in your closet, it feels like fear. Until you check the closet and see that nothing is in there, you will continuously imagine closet bears and feel fear until you check your experience of it. An assumption isn't inherently a contradiction, it's just like a hypothetical guess you make, but in self-inquiry you can realize you don't need to guess what you are because you always are what you are.

And it's not like there's a correct or incorrect answer either. It's a subjective inquiry. If your answer is "I'm right here" then that's okay. Then you simply ask more questions and inquire further, like "do I experience the past? am I separate from my current experience?" etc.

Whatever you assume can't be experienced by definition, or it isn't an assumption anymore. You can't assume something you are already experiencing, because then it just exists.

"Might happen now" makes no sense since "now" is all that can happen. "Might happen" is a division which extrapolates from the present experience because by definition it isn't happening, and in this way it actually does create a distortion in time because it strays from what is occurring now. Because if you truly perceived it as occurring right now, it would be seen that it isn't pointing to anything that "might happen", it is just pointing to what you are already experiencing. You are extrapolating to an experience which isn't happening "right now", like "my crush experiencing this", but there is no experience of that now. You have to think in order to extrapolate your experience to that, because there aren't two experiences, there is just one experience. Thus, when you say "might happen", I consider that as a future extrapolation, because it is not happening right now, and if it is not happening right now then you technically are never affected by it.

if you hypothetically say "I will never experience the future past this moment" then thinking about your crush changes absolutely nothing about your experience, because you do not have to worry about a second hypothetical experience anymore.

"what if it comes true" is an oxymoron, since truth isn't an "if", but "if" is like a future extrapolation that never comes. It's the assumption of a future that feels scary, not even what you are imagining.

what you're imagining is another "now", it isn't a future. if you experienced what you are imagining it would just be the present moment. the reason it feels important or meaningful is because you have this stream of knowledge occurring in relation to past and future about yourself which creates this domino effect, like "if i get this in the future, then this will happen to me after that, then this will happen to my career, then this will happen, then this, this, etc." and you perceive this as "fearing the future", but if you actually look at what you are imagining, it is just a consistent stream of physical present moments, and none of them have anything to do with a psychological past or future at all. if you jump to what you are imagining, you will see that you aren't fearing a future, you are fearing that what you are imagining will occur now. In order for something to happen to you it has to presently occur. if imagining being in that situation causes you to fear another future, and then if you envision yourself jumping into that future, you aren't fearing a future anymore because once you "enter the future" it is simply another present moment with no psychological extrapolation. Your entire life has been this consistent singular present moment with no psychological basis, but you simply mistake the present moment for past and future through your ability to think of "multiple nows." This creates a perception of "me now, me in another now, me in a past now" which is actually just one now.

I think Jamie saved me from the biggest trap for me and probably most people outside of this server, which is that I was basically stuck in this endless conceptual intellectualization, without much results emotionally/mentally. Like the classic idea of an armchair philosopher. Jamie objectively describing the physical occurrence as a singular "click" really streamlined it for me, and set objective parameters to follow, like "ok so if im worrying about this thing, then I obviously don't get it yet, so let me just move away from this intellectual red herring and focus on the emotion/belief instead." In all my years of researching spirituality and all the different teachers I looked at, it never occurred to me that it could just be a permanent ending like that, and I think that really saved me a lot of time in the long run.

Furthermore, I think it's important to see that what is being pointed to is a negation and that it is subtractive in nature, in the sense that it's not a quality/experience or even some way of being or thinking. We aren't saying that you should use your thoughts in a certain way, change your thoughts, think about thoughts in a certain way, or that you should act or behave in a certain way, but just to see what those things are appearing as. What do thoughts appear as? Don't change it, look at it, and see what that implies for you and what it means to you. The answer is your experience of those things, it's not something that is gained or will appear in the future. It is looking at what you have experienced your entire life and then concluding "oh i'll never experience what my thoughts are pointing to, i've only been experiencing one thing which is my life right now."

The mind is division. Descriptions, words, concepts, etc, point to divisions/separation. And they are all mind. Anything related to thought is itself a thought, because "thought" is also a division/categorization. 

You can't relate to thoughts without thinking, because any relation is thinking. 

Thinking is dividing, like "me, them, table, tree, etc." 

Every single word in existence thus points to one experience/occurrence. If you say you experienced a tree AND a cat, you have to experience them both at once. Thus the division isn't experiential at all, it isn't ever experienced, it is simply just thinking/division. It is a concept not experienced, which is the function of thinking. It communicates what is not experienced.

"Proper use" you could say is for communicating non-experience. "Misuse" you could say is for communicating what you are already experiencing.

"Misuse" is like making a blueprint that describes what you are experiencing. The blueprint always fails to do this, because describing is mind, which means it can only dissect and divide experience like a scalpel. Experience isn't a division, but rather, divisions point to experience. The misuse is ultimately that you think you are experiencing divisions, when it is the other way around. The blueprint can't ever describe what you are experiencing because that is like trying to use your finger to point to your experience.

Experientially, have you seen a thought being created?

In accordance with experience, thoughts appear as "things", like "memory", "layers", etc, but none of those things are experienced without thinking, because all those things themselves are actually thoughts since they are divisions. Divisions are concepts which aren't experienced. 

Concepts which aren't experienced, by definition, are beliefs. You can believe that something is on the other side of the door, but you can't hold that belief while being on the other side. Because at that point it isn't a belief, it is experience. You can think of many things which aren't experienced, AKA beliefs/assumptions/thoughts about experience.

Self-knowledge is a belief about experience. Why would anyone have to hold a belief about experience? It is useless. Beliefs are concepts not experienced. It completely defeats the entire purpose of having beliefs/knowledge, because you are always experiencing experience; you are always experiencing yourself. The desire to grasp for self-knowledge is an error in your cognition which occurs because you believe there is knowledge about yourself located in past and future. The sentiment looks like this: "I have experienced past and future, there is knowledge from past and future I can hold in my current experience." The more you examine your experience of past and future, the more you realize you have never experienced either, and thus self-knowledge is a useless recursion.

Conceptually you could say self-knowledge is constructed from memories, because it points to something that isn't occurring now (which must be past), and you never physically experience the future.

If there are thoughts that cause you fear in the waking state, they can cause nightmares while sleeping because you will react to them the same emotionally while sleeping. In my summation, you are "thinking" vivid thoughts while sleeping (dreams), and you feel that thinking (nightmares). The way I see it, dreams are "made of thoughts", it's the same qualia or phenomenon or whatever. Just turned more vivid and life-like. I say this because I have caught my thoughts "turning into dreams" on many occasions while watching myself fall asleep, there is a cusp where the thoughts "absorb" you as the waking state qualia and memory slowly vanishes. 

Dreaming, you could say, is an experience of only vivid thoughts, and no other qualia, and those thoughts are still felt emotionally.

For me, my emotions while dreaming operate the exact same as they do in the waking state since my perception stays non-dual even in the dream state. I don't have any nightmares because nightmares are anxiety. The spookiest dreams I'll have are avoiding physical dangers like bugs or something.

It's not a matter of recognizing you're in a dream, that would be lucid dreaming 24/7. But regardless, the entire emotional system is rerouted, even in the dream state. If you can't feel anxiety, you cant experience nightmares, because nightmares are anxiety. If you look at yourself describing a nightmare, you'll often see that you're describing a future scenario you want to avoid (anxiety). A nightmare about losing your house, for example.

This is how I currently see dreaming at least.
